utterances: That's quite a spread, Jerry.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I'm one of eight children.
And my parents have passed on.
And all of my siblings and I have - were self-educated, self-funded because my parents couldn't afford to send us to college, so we all worked our way through college.
And had you hoped that your children would go to college?
That's right.
And your 20-year-old, did he or she go to college?
My 20-year-old is in his second year of college, going locally.
And I have my daughter in pre pre-school.

Yet, you don't think - it's obviously going to be long time before the economic situation facing your daughter when she graduates from high school is going to become clear, but nevertheless, at least for your son, that he's not going to have as good life as you did?
Well, I don't think that the current environment and with all the debt that we're piling up because of this financial crisis, I'm not sure the opportunity is going to be there for our children.
And what had you hoped your son would do?
You know what?
he's a talented writer, and I hope he becomes a writer.
But, you know, as your previous - or as your current guest said, jobs for journalists are not that great.
I was just going to bringâ€¦
And, of course, (unintelligible) becoming a journalist.
I was just going to bring Gustavo into the conversation and ask if he would encourage your son to get into journalism.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah.
Don't let your son be a journalist.
You know, great writing - there's always going to be a market for great writing.
But nowadays, with the days of the Internet, there has to be a completely different strategy to be able to get a writer out there, whether it's starting with a blog or freelancing.
But to try to pin your future or your hopes on a degree in journalism, I think, would be a waste of a college education.
Well, I think you're right.
I think if people learn a trade or learn how to build stuff, you've got a better opportunity there.
Jerry, thanks very much.
And again, we wish you and your children good luck.
Thank you.
We're talking with Gustavo Arellano on this economic moment.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And Gustavo, you mentioned just a moment ago how the - your parent's generation laughs at the whiny entitled children.
Have you thought about learning how to cut carpet?
Definitely.
That's one thing - there's a great example of myself and my younger brother.
My youngest brother, he just turned 18.
Growing up, my father made me cut the lawn.
He made me accompany him on cleaning swimming pools.
He made me go along with him as a truck driver.
He actually originally wanted me to be a truck driver until I tried to show him otherwise that going to college was optimal for a child, you know, child of immigrants like himself.
So I actually have negligible skills I haven't used in a long time, also, gardening and other blue-collar skills.
My brother, the youngest, the most assimilated of us all, he has none of those skills.
He doesn't cut lawns.
He doesn't clean the swimming pools.
He does wash his plates, and he knows how to fry an egg, but that's really about it.
And yeah, I think people need to have as many skills as possible, and not just on the white-collar skills, but some of the skills that are just essential.
You know, maybe I should go to barber college 'cause everyone's always going to need haircuts, right?
Absolutely.
Let's see if we can get Rodolfo on the line.
Rodolfo is calling us from Denver.
Hello, thank you for taking my call.
Yes, I think you are sending the wrong message, Gustavo.
I'm a Mexican immigrant, and I came here to the United States on the '80s and I used to pick tomatoes in the fields in Ohio.
And what I did, I just finished my college in Mexico and came here to United States, immigrated here and did a master's degree in computer science and economics.
Well, they may have to remove the shuttle from the launch pad to fix it?
Eight?
Good.
And that worked pretty good for me.

I think it's just a matter of (unintelligible) really big faith in the American dream just because the fundamentals of the country, of the economy, I really - well, the fundamentals of country is really good.
The economy is not doing well.
Just because it happened, I think the economy goes back up and down.
And I believe the economy did really well during the '90s because - one of the big factors is because it was a big wave of immigration, it was the biggest wave of immigration of the century.
Well, get a response from Gustavo Arellano?
I think we do come from different situations.
Rodolfo, he's an immigrant just like my parents.
The immigrants who do come here, they do - studies have shown they have a much different perspective on making it here, reaching for the American dream.
And what I'm trying to say is that Rodolfo, he's perfectly, you know, congratulations on achieving the American dream.
I, on the other hand, of course, as a child, as an American growing up here, I do think part of me doesn't have the drive.
I do have a drive.
Obviously if I didn't have a drive I wouldn't be at the position where I'm at today, but not - maybe not the same hunger, same reaching out for that American dream.

And, also, as somebody who's grown up here and just learned all the various economic ways, and maybe just because of my job, I might be a little bit more cynical as to the apparatus of the American economy, especially how we have been for the past 15 or 20 years.
Rodolfo, congratulations, and thanks very much for the phone call.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
And let's see if we can go now to Dawn.
Dawn with us from Brighton in Michigan.
Hi there.
Hi, Dawn.
Go ahead please.
I would - definitely had to call and say that I have a much more positive outlook than a lot of these callers.
I grew up on a dairy farm.
I know how to raise my own food.
I know how to make my own clothes.
And along the way, and working my way through college, an associate degree and a bachelor's degree, I've learned lots of different things.
So I can pull any one of those eight or ten occupations out of my pocket at any time.
If I have to milk cows again for a living, I'll do it.
And people are always going to need milk.
That's right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And what else can you do, Dawn?
I'm a market researcher.
I've been a college professor, an academic adviser.
I'm writing a cookbook.
I sew clothes.
You know, just about anything you have to do.
You just need to pay attention, learn how to take care of yourself.
Well, Gustavo, you think you maybe studied the wrong thing in college?
(Soundbite of laughter)
The only skills I know is how to write columns about Mexicans and how to expose pedophile priests.
That's all I have.
Well, I think there may be demand for that in the future, too.
